Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2014 10:43PM NWArtLady wrote: Sparkle, I'm sorry you are having such a frustrating time!
Posts.Title: 29, not taken seriously because "I'm too young" Sparkle2829 Lionesse2

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2014 02:06PM NWArtLady wrote: Sparkle, good for you for standing up for yourself! You have to be your own best advocate in the health care system, I'm afraid.  Your NP sounds like a great support, I 'm glad she's on your side! When I have questions about specific tests, etc., I find the Mayo clinic's website a good place to get good, trustworthy information (I'm a librarian).  For example, here is their site with info on breast tissue biopsies: Mayo Clinic Breast biopsy I highly suggest you bring someone along with you (partner, friend, family member, etc.) to your appointment.  Appointments with doctors can be overwhelming and it is so helpful to have another set of ears in the room with you.  Also, ask the person who goes with you to bring a pad of paper and a pen to take notes. It's amazing how helpful it is to have these notes to go over later on when your mind is not swimming so much. And don't let them pass on you saying that you have no family history of BC. I don't either and yet here I am! That is old information. Get the answers you need so you can sleep at night. Good luck! I'll be thinking about you on Thursday!!
Posts.Title: 29, not taken seriously because "I'm too young" Sparkle2829 Lionesse2

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2014 10:34PM NWArtLady wrote: Hi Sparkle,  Glad you got to meet with the surgeon today! It sounds like he was listening to you. The mammogram will hopefully give you more information.  When I don't understand a term or process, I like to go to the Mayo Clinic website as they explain things very well and I trust the information will be accurate: Mayo Clinic I think the discussion about doing a biopsy that will remove the lump is due to the size of the lump: in the process of taking the biopsy, the lump would be removed because of the amount of tissue that needs to be taken to run the tests on it. Does that make sense? It seems like a lot of the professionals are thinking it's benign - here's to hoping they are right!!
Posts.Title: 29, not taken seriously because "I'm too young" Sparkle2829 Lionesse2

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 03:29PM NWArtLady wrote: Sherry and Pam, have you seen the More Tips (and a Shopping List) for Getting Through Chemo in the Chemotherapy - Before, During and After forum? http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/706846?page=28
Posts.Title: I am finding it hard to ask for help pamelahope NWArtLady

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 04:42PM NWArtLady wrote: I'm sorry to hear of your debilitating nausea Mariasnow!  I lived on Zofran, ginger ale and small, frequent meals, especially while on AC.  Things got better on Taxol and Herceptin and now I'm on Herceptin and Tamoxifen with little to no SE's (knock on wood!).  I spoke with my onc about L-Glutamine while on Taxol and he highly suggested I take it to help with neuropathy.  I also did acupuncture to help me with digestive issues and found relief that way. I also was fortunate enough to be able to take small, 20 minute naps while at work and that helped tremendously.  Walking every day also kept me going. Exercise is crucial! So is moisturizing. I grew to really appreciate shea butter lotions. I wish you the best as you go through this very difficult time. The ladies and gentlemen on these boards are the best and always full of good advice. I hope you have friends that will step up and help you out while you go through this.
Posts.Title: Taxol v adriamycin / cytoxan ahdjdbcjdjdbkf ahdjdbcjdjdbkf

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 10:14PM NWArtLady wrote: This is great! I have been using humor throughout to help me and I'm so glad to see others doing the same. I have always had a thing for blue hair and one of the first things my husband and I did was to go wig shopping; I got a gorgeous blue one that gets me compliments wherever I go.  I also got one that goes from yellow to green (top to bottom) and is beautiful. I work at an arts college and some of the students gave me wigs: a white one and a blonde one. I'm really known for the blue one, especially in the chemo ward. Prior to chemo, I had waist-length blonde hair... I'm a photographer, so I started a photo series wherein I've been photographing myself with bald friends (they've all been male thus far).  Good fun! On a serious note, when I was diagnosed I stopped and really looked at my life. I asked myself if I was doing what I wanted to do and is there anything I would change. I'm happy to say that no, there isn't anything I would change (that is in my control)!  That was a real gift. I love the stories, ladies! Keep them up!
Posts.Title: So, you won the chemo lottery? TRY to find the humor! PlantLover fredntan

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2012 09:20PM NWArtLady wrote: Truffles, I did a similar treatment and while I did continue to work, there were days when I had to go home early or even take a nap while at work.  My supurvisor and coworkers helped to make my job as low-stress as possible and were very flexible with my schedule.  Yes, I did work throughout, but I did not have to be "mentally present and completely "on" in a high stress hospital environment 10 hours a day, 5 days a week".  If I had, I would not have made it, no way.   Usually I work 2-3 jobs + go to graduate school + take care of family, so I am not a slacker; chemo is HARD as is radiation, and this is the time to take care of yourself. Hopes this helps! Feel free to PM me if you have any questions.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 07:39PM NWArtLady wrote: Congrats lstreett!  I was on the exact same regimen as you and finished the day after you did! Feels good to be done with that component of treatment. Now for a little break and then daily radiation for 6 weeks... I'll also be doing Herceptin-only for a year, so I'll be back with my lovely oncolgy nurses soon (every 3 weeks).  I did bring them chocolate-covered macadamia nuts (I was raised in Hawaii) to celebrate the end of the chemo component on the last day and they loved it. Looking forward to the return of hair and my mind, and for my nails to clear up and stop hurting!! DebinUtah, I've had a constantly running nose for some time now - I think it's partially due to the lack of nose hairs...? I'm not sure. But I recall in the beginning reading that a runny nose is par for the course with chemo and have always kept tissue nearby. Now, if only my nose would stop bleeding! Soon, soon. Here's to a happy and healthy new year!
Posts.Title: August 2011 chemo, anyone w/ me?! vtellen MizMarie

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2012 09:53PM NWArtLady wrote: I'm sorry to hear that you are having a hard time, Justina.  Have you discussed this with your doctor?  You have been through so much, it's no wonder that we all cry at the drop of a hat! Mine has me on anti-depressants for the time being and I find they have helped me immensely.  When we were in treatment, there was action, we were doing things to fight this damn disease; now we are moving away from seeing our medical team daily and it is a huge shift! I am just starting an After Breast Cancer class at my hospital - we have been through hell and back and I'm looking for tools to get back normal.  Is there anything in your community akin to this? Perhaps at a Gilda's Club or the like? I also find that calling the American Cancer Society helpful for talking to someone or for finding resources. They are at 1-800-227-2345 I hope you are able to find some relief.  Do take care of yourself and let us know how you are doing!

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 02:47PM NWArtLady wrote: Oh jacee, I'm so sorry to hear of your throwing up!!  Sounds horrible.  Yes, everyone reacts to the medications differently.  Pam, hopefully you will not have the same reaction as jacee.  I was fortunate and did not have any nausea throughout treatment. If it will make you feel less anxious, perhaps if you tuck a plastic bag in your day bag to use in case you get nauseous? I find that if I prepared for something to happen, then it does not usually happen.  I'm not sure if someone has already said this, so forgive me everyone if I am repeating.  I found that it was a good idea for me to bring a bag along with items for the day as the infusions can take several hours (accessing my port, blood draw, onc visit, infusion, etc) so I brought my laptop and 2 sets of headphones with a splitter along so my husband and I could watch a movie during my infusion. A good book for each of you is nice, as are snacks.  My infusion floor had sandwiches for the patients, but no food for the visitors, so my husband would either bring something or step out to get himself a bite to eat.   Note, if you have any food expenses while at the hospital, these can be deducted from your taxes, so keep you receipt! This also goes for mileage and parking expenses. I'm so glad your friend is going with you!!  This whole thing is tiring physically, mentally, and emotionally. Whenever a friend or family member offers help, take them up on it. It does both you and them great good and makes your relationships stronger.
Posts.Title: I am finding it hard to ask for help pamelahope NWArtLady

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 03:02PM NWArtLady wrote: Hi sherryh16!  Rant away!!  We know what you are going through and are here for you. For the bad taste in my mouth and to avoid mouth sores, I rinsed and spit after each meal and snack a mixture of water and a little baking soda.  I was getting mouth sores prior to doing this and they went away and stayed away with this "mouthwash."  I kept a little container of baking soda at my desk and would pop into the ladies room with my mug and baking soda and make myself a little mixture and would rinse and spit 3-4 times.  Helped with the funny taste as well.  I now use a toothpaste with baking soda because I liked the clean feeling so much! I loved my lorezapam during treatment and still keep some nearby (just in case).  It helped with the anxiety and fear and helped me sleep.  I had it with my infusion (along with anti-nausea meds, chemo, and saline). The chemos are cumulative, so do work that fact into your plan. I found that if I took 20 minute naps during the day around 3:00, that they helped tremendously. I have an amazing boss and I was fortunate enough to be able to make that happen.  It actually made me a better and more efficient employee! I, too, work with the public and I did different things depending on my mood.  On days that I felt like rockin' it, I went bald! I put in some nice earrings, a little makeup and rocked it!  On cold days I wore cute hats.  I went hat shopping and got several so I would have one to match my outfit.  There were inexpensive ones at the treatment center so I was able to get a few.  My hair is now coming back, but I still wear the hats 'cause they are so cute!  I also got some wigs to wear and wore them as I felt like it.  My onc's favorite was a blue one I would wear to my infusions - the nurses loved it too!  It was fun to have a blue wig to wear on those days.  I hope you can find what works for you! Take care!!
Posts.Title: I am finding it hard to ask for help pamelahope NWArtLady

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 12:55PM NWArtLady wrote: Hello ladies, I saw that several of us are having trouble with rough and burning tongues - I have found that if I rinse my mouth out with a combination of water and baking soda (swish and spit) after each meal, that I get great relief from the burning sensation. It has also kept the mouth sores at bay. Hope this helps!

Posts.Content: May 27, 2012 02:01AM NWArtLady wrote: Pamelahope, when someone is diagnosed with this damn disease, our friends and family feel so powerless to do anything.  Giving rides, visiting, making dinners, cleaning, these are things they can do.  Please allow them to do these things for you.  It helps them, it helps you, and it helps your family.  It is hard to accept the help in the beginning, but it truly helps everyone when you do. To help spread out the tasks and to give people control over thier helping (they choose what to do and when) and to give you and your husband control over what happens and when, I suggest using the free website lotsahelpinghands. It enabled me to schedule meals to be dropped by after chemo and for visits and other items.  Here is their website:  http://www.lotsahelpinghands.com  Take care.

Posts.Title: August 2011 chemo, anyone w/ me?! vtellen MizMarie

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 07:45PM NWArtLady wrote: Hello folks, May I join you?  I began radiation last week and had my 8th treatment this morning.  Lovely people, my radiation therapists.  I use an ABC machine while doing radiation - it enables me to breathe in deeply and hold my chest wall away from my heart so as to avoid radiating it.  This is great because I did Adriamycin and am doing Herceptin, both of which can do heart damage. I am having one issue, though: after treatment 1, I developed severe redness on my breast and some swelling.  2 radiation oncologists say this should not happen this soon... they think it might be an infection. I went back to my breast surgeon and he says it is not an infection and wants me to take anti-inflammatory meds and check back in a week.  Has anyone had this happen to them?
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 04:44PM NWArtLady wrote: Just came back to work from tx #11.  A little tired, but I think that's from the drive there and back!  Ah, traffic.  Still beet red, but not painful and the swelling seems to be going down. Maybe the anti-inflammatories are doing the trick. On the way out I told them all my favorite bad joke: "see you next month!" They all paused and said: no, wait, what, no, oh, I get it...   I love saying that at the end of each month.  For my coworkers, it's gotten old so I enjoy having new folks on which to inflict my humor!
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2012 09:19PM NWArtLady wrote: Chef, I'm down to 7 treatments left.  And yes, you're right about the burning! Someone on these boards told us about using honey to help and I found Medihoney and have been using it at night. The nurses and my Doc are all surprised at how well my skin is doing and I attribute it to the Calendula cream and the Medihoney.  Today they told me to use Domeboro in the evening. We'll see if that helps! I'm running around the house topless these days; I feel like I'm back in Yap! Oh, and this past weekend I had to fly to a funeral at the last minute and was told by my oncologist and radiation oncologist to use a compression sleeve while on the plane. Fortunately I was able to get a prescription quickly and get the sleeve in time. It was tight, but doable.  Anafoefana, I'm so glad it was not LE!! One last thing: today I almost forgot to go to my treatment! I was so absorbed in work that it slipped my mind. I was able to get there just in time, but it was close! Give me 3 days off and you get nothing but trouble...
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2012 10:05AM NWArtLady wrote: So glad to hear everyone is healing and moving on!  For those still in and finishing soon: the end is in sight and it is SO good! I finished March 2 and am doing well. Some dryness, but the scaling on my nipple is gone. I still use calendula cream daily and it helps. My fatigue is almost non-existent and I find daily exercise (walking) helps greatly at keeping it away. Woo Hoo!!

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 02:23PM NWArtLady wrote: newksmom100, I also have been having thickening of my areola and nipple tenderness; my nurse says it's normal.  Breast is tender too and red and swollen - and I'm only on #11. It's gonna be fun, I can tell... My treatment flow sounds similar to everyone else's: in and out pretty quick, nice techs.  I'm a visual artist so at my MD visit this week I mentioned my interest in seeing the xrays they have been taking every week.  He was glad to show them to me and even showed me the planning images which show the radiation field, etc.  It was fascinating!  It also gives me peace of mind to see how things are being done. I am also a librarian and information is key!
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 12:32PM NWArtLady wrote: Ladies, thanks for the info on the lashes and brows!  Oh, the joys of chemo.   You guys are the best, I appreciate your letting me know that this is "normal" and that I can expect it possibly happen multiple time. As to the question regarding when we can say we HAD bc (I love that word, had), a wise friend told me that as soon as I had the surgery that removed the tumors, I was cancer-free.  They cut it out.  In my case, the chemo and radiation are preventative since I had (there's that lovely word again!) a grade 3, Her2 positive tumor (the other tumor was benign).  So I consider myself cancer-free right now!! I had a mammogram between chemo and radiation.  They were able to give me the all-clear right there in the clinic.  I asked the nurse if I could hug her and I began to cry with joy!  She let me hug her and then asked where my support person was... he was in the waiting room and I was overjoyed to share the good news.  Now I just hope to be able to get that good news every 6 months!!

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 02:54PM NWArtLady wrote: Momine, I, too, am purple; it's mostly under my arm - my scar from the node removal is getting it the worst.  It hurts!! Hang in there, we'll get through this! Ossa, a friend of mine (who went through all of this and is the Provost of the college where I work) told me that once they removed the tumor, we were cancer free!! I've been holding on to that throughout and find great comfort in it.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 06:31PM NWArtLady wrote: Ralston – thank you for the info and the tips! Chef127, Kaycee234,  – hang in there!  And yes, it is ok to be mad, sad and every other emotion you are feeling.  We have been through hell and we are still going through it!  Kaycee234, I also talk to my Grandmother and wear her bracelet to every treatment.  She is with me throughout all of this. Banba – I have not had any headaches or achiness from the rads.  I do stretch my arm gently to keep it from tightening up too much. Lifechanging2011 – you had cancer and no matter the stage or size or whatever, it sucks!!  And it is hard!! All – I’m relived to hear that I am not the only one have swelling and redness from the get-go; thank you for sharing!
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 10:13AM NWArtLady wrote: Momine, no dressing room?!? That sucks! I'd say something to them about that - you have to be there every day for weeks and you at least deserve the dignity of a changing room.  Banba, do you also not have a changing room? At least you can get the cream on soon after treatment. Rockym, I, too, am feeling more fatigued. I just hold on to the fact that things will slowly get back to normal after we are all done with treatments (right?!?). And I know what you mean about chemopause!  I am waking up in the middle of the night sweating, I even found myself tempted to take off my hat when I was talking to a group of students at work due to a hot flash! I didn't, though, because I dd not want to distract them from what I was saying. I'm going to get some aloe to supplement my calendula - y'all are always a fount of good information!!

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 07:03PM NWArtLady wrote: Tomorrow's my last day!!  I can't wait.  This is going to be a VERY good weekend! The pain has gone down with my boosts and the bad area under my arm is actually beginning to heal. It still hurts to lift my arm and place it in the arm rest during treatment, but as I said, only one more!! Then one more week of work until I have a week of vacation - spring break here I come!!  The thought of this trip is what helped me get through surgery, chemo, radiation...  I hope everyone else gets through quickly and painlessly.  And congratulations to those who are done!! And J-Bug, I'm afraid I have no idea as to your question above. I hope you are able to find an answer!
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 07:26PM NWArtLady wrote: Yay Maggie!!! Thanks for your comment of Tamox, bgirl. I start it soon and am wondering what it will bring. (Hopefully no recurrence!!) newksmom, can you see a physical therapist?  Mine has me doing stretches on my surgery/radiation side. I take a pole or a cane or the like and hold it with my left hand and with my right I stretch my left arm up towards the ceiling.  It's a gentle arc towards the ceiling, being careful to not overdo it.
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 10:46PM NWArtLady wrote: ABC stands for Active Breathing Coordinator.  You can read more about it here:www.swedish.org/Services/Cance... It's like a snorkel in my mouth; having grown up in Micronesia swimming in the ocean, it's very easy for me to use.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 07:29PM NWArtLady wrote: DONE! I got hugs from everyone, I gave cards to my team, it was a great day.
